attributes.title: Job design and well-being in agile development teams
attributes.description: In this project we will examine a job demands-resource model for agile development teams. We would like to answer the question how specific agile project management practices predict job demands and job resources as well as positive and negative occupational wellbeing and attitudinal outcomes. It is expected that agile practices as a new work approach explains additional variance in the named relationships controlling for rather traditional high performance work systems characteristics. Furthermore it is expected that organizational as well as individual aspects strongly influence the relationships and effects of agile practices on job characteristics and wellbeing.

q2.value:
Direct effects 

1. Agile practices are
a) Positively related to job satisfaction and job engagement, while controlling for high-performance work system.
b) Negatively related to work fatigue and turnover intention, while controlling for high-performance work system.

2. Self-organized autonomous teamwork is 
a) Negatively related to hindering and challenging job demands, while controlling for high performance work system
b) Positively related to job autonomy, peer support and engaging task characteristics, while controlling for high performance work system

3. Iterative planning and incrementation are
a) Negatively related to hindering and challenging job demands, while controlling for high performance work system
b) Positively related to job autonomy, feedback from job and engaging task characteristics, while controlling for high performance work system

4. Customer relation is
a) Positively related to feedback from job and engaging task characteristics, while controlling for high performance work system

5. Daily stand-up and visualization of work progress are
a) Negatively related to hindering and challenging job demands, while controlling for high performance work system
b) Positively related to job autonomy, feedback from job and peer support, while controlling for high performance work system

6. Retrospectives are 
a) Negatively related to hindering and challenging job demands, while controlling for high performance work system
b) Positively related to job autonomy, feedback from job and peer support, while controlling for high performance work system


Mediation effects

7. Hindering and challenging job demands mediate the negative relationship between agile practices and negative outcomes (fatigue and turnover intention).

8. Job resources mediate the positive relationship between agile practices and positive outcomes (engagement and job satisfaction).


Moderation effects

9. Organizational support and empowering leadership moderate
a) The positive relationships between agile practices and job resources, such that the relationships are stronger when organizational support and empowering leadership are high and weaker when organizational support and empowering leadership are low.
b) The negative relationships between agile practices and job demands, such that the relationships are stronger when organizational support and empowering leadership are high and weaker when organizational support and empowering leadership are low.

10. Personal resources (extraversion, emotional stability, conscientiousness, proactive personality, agility, resilience, individual renewal) moderate
a) The positive relationships between agile practices and job resources, such that the relationships are stronger when personal resources are high and weaker when personal resources are low.
b) The negative relationships between agile practices and job demands, such that the relationships are stronger when personal resources are high and weaker when personal resources are low.

11. Organizational support and empowering leadership moderate
a) The positive relationships between agile practices and positive outcomes, such that the relationships are stronger when organizational support and empowering leadership are high and weaker when organizational support and empowering leadership are low.
b) The negative relationships between agile practices and negative outcomes, such that the relationships are stronger when organizational support and empowering leadership are high and weaker when organizational support and empowering leadership are low.

12. Personal resources (extraversion, emotional stability, conscientiousness, proactive personality, agility, resilience, individual renewal) moderate
a) The positive relationships between agile practices and positive outcomes, such that the relationships are stronger when personal resources are high and weaker when personal resources are low.
b) The negative relationships between agile practices and negative outcomes, such that the relationships are stronger when personal resources are high and weaker when personal resources are low.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Longitudinal survey design with two measuring times

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Data is collected via an online survey within the German speaking market (Germany, Switzerland, Austria). Participants have to meet two requirements: 1. they have to work in software or hardware development and 2. they have to work within an agile team. The link to the survey is shared via professional network platforms, different mailing lists and personal network. The participants are not paid any money but will have the possibility to win an one hour coaching session. We have started collecting data on 07.04.2020.

q11.value: Our target sample size is 200-250 participants for both measuring times. We will attempt to recruit up to 300 or rather as many participants as possible, assuming that not all will participate in the second measuring time.

question.value:
The questionnaire includes 160 items all measured using a 5-point likert scale (1="strongly disagree"; 5 = "strongly agree").

The following outcome variables were selected:
- Work fatigue is measured using 9 items from Frone & Tidwell (2015)
- Work engagement is measured using 9 items from Rich et al. (2010)
- Job satisfaction is measured using 3 items from Tripp, Riemenschneider & Thatcher (2016)
- Turnover intention is measured using 3 items from Bozeman & Perrewe (2001)

The following predictors and mediating variables were selected:
- Agile practices is a multidimensional scale with the scales Self-organized autonomous teamwork, Iterative planning, Incrementation, Customer relation, Daily stand-up, Retrospective, Visualization of the work progress. The seven scales are measured with 3 or 4 items from the scales by Tripp, Riemenschneider & Thatcher (2016), Tuomivaara, Lindholm, & Känsälä (2017) as well as one scale self-developed.
- Hindering job demands are operationalized with the scales role conflict and role ambiguity (3 items each from Haynes et al., 1999) as well as work interruptions (3 items from Semmer et al., 1998).
- Challenging job demands are operationalized with the scales workload (3 items from Spector & Jex, 1998), time pressure (3 items from Semmer et al., 1998) and cognitive processing (3 items from Stegman et al., 2010).
- Job resources include job autonomy (9 items from Stegman et al., 2010), feedback from job, skill variety, task variety, task identity, task significance (3 items each from Stegman et al., 2010) and peer support (3 items from Haynes et al. 1999).

The following control variable was selected:
- High performance work system is measured using 9 items from Etchegaray & Thomas (2015)

The following moderator variables and measurement were selected:
- Organizational support is measured using  4 items from Eisenberger & Huntington (1986)
- Empowering leadership is measured using the 5 items from Martin, Liao & Campbell (2013)
- Extraversion, neuroticism and conscientiousness are measured using 4 items each from Rammstedt & John (2005)
- Core self evaluations are measured with the 12 items by Stumpp et al. (2010)
- Proactive personality is measured using 4 items from Parker & Sprigg (1999, orginally from Bateman & Crant, 1993)
- Agility and Individual renewal are measured using 3 items each from Braun et al. (2017)
- Resilience is measured using 3 items from Cai et al. (2018)
Data will be analyzed using multiple regression models.

b) The negative relationships between agile practices and negative outcomes, such that the relationships are stronger when personal resources are high and weaker when personal resources are low.

summary.value:
This data complements the Journal of Business Research article: Kühn, F., Lichters, M., & Krey, N. (2020). It might look pretty but how does it feel? The importance of need for touch in online retailing for produce. Journal of Business Research(forthcoming).

Study 3 in the article offers a solution for NFT’s negative effects on WTP difference (offline-online) observed in online produce retailing: video clips as visual design features displaying haptic evaluations of a product. In addition, results highlight an important boundary condition, namely NFT does not negatively impact online produce with low-touch diagnosticity.

This OSF component provides the video clips used with Study 3.

attributes.title: Protocol of a rapid scoping review: Pregnancy during the evolving pandemic of Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)
attributes.description: During the evolving pandemic of confirmed cases of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), it is imperative to understand the effect of COVID-19 on vulnerable groups, such as pregnant women. This protocol elaborates the strategy of literature search and implementation of a rapid scoping review to investigates the latest published scientific evidence of clinical manifestation and recommendation for management for pregnant women with COVID-19.
tags: Severe acute respiratory syndrome corona virus 2

summary.value:
The aim of the rapid scoping review is to investigate the most recent published scientific literature evidence on the clinical feature and management recommendation for COVID-19 affected pregnant women. The review will be conducted based on the recommendation of Arksey and O’Malley (2005), and Levac and colleagues (2010). And the result will be reported according to the guideline of the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses’ Extension for Scoping Reviews (PRISMA-ScR) (Micah DJ Peters et al., 2020). 

To extract the relevant records, a systematic and replicable search strategy was formed considering two themes: pregnant women, and COVID-19 (see supplemental files for the PubMed search strategy). on March 27, 2020, we implemented the search across four scientific literature database (a) PubMed (ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/), (b) Embase (embase.com), (c) Scopus (scopus.org), and (d) Web of Science (webofknowledge.com). Additionally, we implemented a hand search in the “Global research on coronavirus disease (COVID-19)” database, managed by the World Health Organization (WHO) (https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/global-research-on-novel-coronavirus-2019-ncov). The search strategy development and its implementation was performed by MH and TA. Next, two investigators(MH and GMK) will independently screen the title, abstract and the full-text for the eligible studies. Data extraction and synthesis of the evidence will be done by MH and GMK, collaboratively. 

The search strategy initially identified 52 unique studies and 17 duplicates published between 01 January 2019 to 27 March 2020 (Dated 27 March 2020). These studies included a wide range of evidence - including case studies or reports, original research, expert consensus, editorial, correspondence, and review studies (systematic review and rapid review). Eligible studies will be identified after screening their title, abstract, and the full-text. 

Evidence from the eligible studies will be charted in three categories: 
1. Study characteristics: type of research, location of the study, number of participants, etc. 
2. Clinical features of the COVID-19 pregnant women: clinical presentation, radiological and laboratory findings, medication prescribed, maternal outcome, etc.
3. Management recommendation for COVID-19 pregnant women: prevention, isolation and screening, diagnostic procedures, management of suspected cases, management of confirmed cases, clinical monitoring of confirmed cases and management during the antenatal stage, delivery stage, and postnatal stage, etc. 

The evidence related to COVID-19 among pregnant women will be reported in a narrative format and with the help of tables. No ethical approval is required for the study, and there was no funding available for the development, implementation, and reporting of this rapid scoping review. Furthermore, no competing interests were reported by the authors.


References: 
Arksey, H., & O’Malley, L. (2005). Scoping studies: Towards a methodological framework. International Journal of Social Research Methodology, 8(1), 19–32. https://doi.org/10.1080/1364557032000119616

Levac, D., Colquhoun, H., & O’Brien, K. K. (2010). Scoping studies: Advancing the methodology. Implementation Science, 5(1), 69. https://doi.org/10.1186/1748-5908-5-69

Micah DJ Peters, Christina Godfrey, Patricia McInerney, Zachary Munn, Andrea C. Tricco, & Hanan Khalil. (2020). Chapter 11: Scoping reviews. In E. Aromataris & Z. Munn (Eds.), Joanna Briggs Institute Reviewer’s Manual,. JBI. https://reviewersmanual.joannabriggs.org/

data.name: Search strategy for the PubMed literature.docx

extra.selectedFileName: Search strategy for the PubMed literature.docx

attributes.title: The effects of intermittent fasting on cardiovascular risk factors and cardiovascular disease. A scoping review
attributes.description: A scoping review to understand the effects of intermittent fasting on cardiovascular risk factors and cardiovascular diseases. For decades, many pre-clinical and clinical studies have shown beneficial health effects, beyond weight loss, of intermittent fasting. Particularly with the rising disease burden of cardiovascular diseases, this review is important to understand the potential effect of intermittent fasting on cardiovascular and cerebrovascular health. This can potentially improve the outcome of intervention and reduce the disease burden through public health interventions. This study aims to identify the gaps in the current knowledge to guide future studies.

summary.value: This is a scoping review to understand the effect of intermittent fasting on cardiovascular risk factors and cardiovascular diseases. With the current impact of cardiovascular diseases on the society, financially and socially, this study aims to identify the lapse in the current knowledge to guide possible public health interventions and future studies in this field.

registration_responses.summary: This is a scoping review to understand the effect of intermittent fasting on cardiovascular risk factors and cardiovascular diseases. With the current impact of cardiovascular diseases on the society, financially and socially, this study aims to identify the lapse in the current knowledge to guide possible public health interventions and future studies in this field.

attributes.title: The Effect of Partisan Conflict and Game Frames on COVID-19 Attitudes and Behaviors
attributes.description:
Political Communications scholars have long noted – and generally bemoaned – the tendency for the media to cover political issues using “partisan conflict” or “game” frame (Patterson 1993, Capella and Jameison 1997, Paterson 2015). Partisan conflict frames describe political events as sites for conflict between the two parties (Han and Federico 2017). Partisan game frames take this a step further, describing political events in terms of who “won” or “lost,” instead of in terms of the events’ substantive importance (Patterson 1993). This coverage, sometimes referred to as “horse-race” coverage in the context of political campaigns, is thought to reflect a reflex among journalists to see politics as a game played by key individuals to gain personal power and advancement (Weaver 1972). While game-frame coverage is most studied in political campaigns, it is a common element of most political news, including coverage of Congress, the President, and even the bureaucracy (Lichter and Amundonson 1994, Lawrence 2000, Cohen 2008). Game frame coverage has been blamed for producing a less-informed public, creating cynicism and reducing public interest in government, and of warping the issue agenda by emphasizing issues that are controversial over those that are substantively important. Frames that emphasize partisan wins and losses also exacerbate affective polarization by turning politics into a game played by two side trying to win rather than an attempt by disagreeing actors to arrive at good public policy (Han and Federico 2017, 2018). Apologists for game frame coverage argue that emphasizing the competitive aspects of politics increases political interest by producing journalism that is more compelling.

What happens, however, when the journalistic instinct to frame issues as in terms of conflict runs into a global public health crisis such as the one created by COVID-19? Conflict and game frame coverage of political campaigns can be justified by the fact that elections are, in fact, contests with winners and losers. This can hardly be said about the response to COVID-19, where we might hope that policy response will be guided by scientific experts to minimize harm to the public. Yet, while the federal government’s legislative response to COVID-19 has been characterized by a previously unthinkable amount of partisan unity, the pandemic has been the occasion for considerable partisan in-fighting as well. Democrats’ messaging strategy around the pandemic has emphasized quick action to stem the pandemic, but also sharp criticism of Republican officeholders’ response to this threat. Some Republicans, on the other hand, have attempted to downplay the threat posed by COVID-19, while criticizing Democrats for either politicizing the pandemic or fumbling the response in states with Democratic governors. These conflicts provide the opportunity for journalists to employ game or partisan conflict frames in their coverage of the pandemic, turning the issue from a global health threat into a partisan issue. Indeed, polling shows sizable gaps between Republicans and Democrats in concern about the COVID-19, as well as health behaviors and policy preferences in response to the pandemic (Gadarian, Goodman, and Pepinsky 2020).

In this article we evaluate the effect of game or conflict frames on public responses to the COVID-19 pandemic. We hypothesize that conflict framing, and especially game framing, will exacerbate the partisan divide in concern about the pandemic, support for drastic action to reduce its spread, and willingness to engage in personal actions to avoid contracting or disseminating the SARS-CoV-2 virus. Further, we test whether these frames increase cynicism about and reduce trust in the government’s ability to respond to the pandemic. Finally, we test the hypothesis, suggested by defenders of game framing in political campaigns, that these frames increase interest in the issue, as compared to coverage that does not frame the pandemic in game or conflict terms. We evaluate these using a framing experiment in which individuals are randomly assigned to read newspaper articles that frame legislative action in response to the pandemic using game frames, conflict frames, or a substantive frame that emphasizes the substantive effects of the policy.

q2.value:
H1: Compared to the non-partisan frame condition, the partisan conflict frame will increase concern about coronavirus, support for mitigation strategies, willingness to engage in personal health behaviors; will decrease approval of actors’ actions; and will worsen beliefs about the pandemic’s effects more among Democrats than among Republicans.

H2: Compared to the non-partisan frame condition, the partisan game frame will increase concern about coronavirus, support for mitigation strategies, willingness to engage in personal health behaviors; will decrease approval of actors’ actions; and will worsen beliefs about the pandemic’s effects more among Democrats than among Republicans.

H3: Compared to the partisan conflict frame condition, the partisan game frame will increase concern about coronavirus, support for mitigation strategies, willingness to engage in personal health behaviors; will decrease approval of actors’ actions; and will worsen beliefs about the pandemic’s effects more among Democrats than among Republicans.

H4: Compared to the non-partisan frame condition, the partisan conflict frame condition will decrease trust, increase cynicism, and increase interest in consuming pandemic news.

H5: Compared to the non-partisan frame condition, the partisan game frame condition will decrease trust, increase cynicism, and increase interest in consuming pandemic news.

H6: Compared to the partisan conflict frame condition, the partisan game frame condition will decrease trust, increase cynicism, and increase interest in consuming pandemic news.

H7a: Compared to the non-partisan frame condition, the partisan game frame condition will increase affective polarization among Republicans.

H7b: Compared to the non-partisan frame condition, the partisan game frame condition will increase affective polarization among Democrats.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
We employ a three-condition experiment to evaluate the effect of conflict and game-framing on attitudes and beliefs about the COVID-19 pandemic. In each condition participants read three news stories about the pandemic that were framed in non-partisan, partisan conflict, or partisan game frames. There were two partisan game-frame conditions; in one, Democrats were portrayed as winning in two of the three stories, in the other Republicans were portrayed as winning in two of the three stories. After reading these stories, participants answered several batteries of questions measuring concern about the pandemic, support for mitigation strategies, approval of various actors’ responses to the pandemic, personal health behaviors adopted in response to the pandemic, beliefs about the effects of the pandemic, trust in political actors to manage the pandemic going forward, cynicism about the government response, and interest in consuming news about the pandemic.

All participants first read a short article describing a brief timeline of COVID-19 related events going back to the first detection of the disease in Wuhan, China. This article was intended to set common expectations about the purpose of the experiment; further, time spent on this article served as a pre-treatment attention check, since all participants read the same article. After this article, participants read three articles about different aspects of the COVID-19 pandemic. One article was about Senate negotiations over the two trillion dollar “phase three” stimulus bill signed into law on March 27th, one about the lack of testing available in parts of the United States, and one about…? All articles were based on actual articles in the New York Times or Washington Post and were shortened considerably to 250-300 words. In the non-partisan condition, the headline and text of these articles were adapted to emphasis the substantive impact of the legislation and to remove direct references to partisanship or partisan conflict. In the partisan conflict condition the headlines and text were altered to emphasize partisan disagreement and fighting over the issue. In the game frame condition the headlines and text were adapted to advance a claim that one party was “winning” and another “losing” because of the issue; one article portrayed the Democrats as winning, one the Republicans, and one that both sides claimed victory. Full treatment text is as an attachment.

q7.value:
This study employs block random assignment with seven blocks defined by Lucid-supplied Party ID. Each group in the ANES 7-point Party ID classification is a block.

Randomization will be conducted through qualtrics's randomizer function.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be 3,711 subjects recruited by Lucid to take part in a “Study on COVID-19 Coverage.” We use Lucid’s measure of party identification to classify participants as Republicans or Democrats, including leaners as partisans. All will be screened to be US residents and over the age of 18. We will use procedures described by Prims and Motyl (2018) and Kennedy et  al. (2019) to remove likely bots and non-US respondents using VPS services. We will also remove subjects who spend less than eight seconds on the first, common article.

q12.value: A power analysis conducted via simulation in R showed that 1,237 subjects per condition provide .8 power to detect a 2x3 treatment by covariate interaction of size Cohen's d = .2

question.value: The manipulated variable is the treatment assignment, which determines which set of three articles the subject will read.

We measure eight clusters of dependent variables. For the first five, we expect that partisan conflict and game framed news will increase partisan divisions on the issues.
•	Concern: We measured this using two items, one asking “How concerned are you about the corona virus outbreak?,” using a five-point scale from “extremely concerned” to “not at all concerned,” and a second item asking respondents whether they would say that the coronavirus outbreak was “A significant crisis,” “A serious problem but not a crisis,” “A minor problem,” or “Not a problem at all.” To avid ceiling effects, we added a follow up for those answering “A significant crisis” asking if it was “the most significant in my lifetime,” “among the most significant in my lifetime,” or “not among the most significant in my lifetime.” 
•	Support for mitigation strategies: We asked participants how necessary they thought eight different policy actions: Restricting domestic travel within the U.S., Requiring most businesses other than grocery stores and pharmacies to close, Issuing "Shelter in Place" orders that require people to stay home except for essential trips and errands, Closing K-12 schools, Limiting restaurants to carry-out only, Postponing upcoming state primary elections, Mobilizing the National Guard, Tracking citizens' movement using electronic devices to learn who newly diagnosed cases have been in contact with, and Imposing heavy fines on people who violate "Stay at Home" orders. All used a six-point response scale from “Extremely necessary” to “Extremely unnecessary.”
•	Personal health behaviors: We asked respondents how willing they would be to take eight different actions to reduce the impact of the coronavirus outbreak: Leave home only when I absolutely have to, Cancel travel plans, Avoid contact with people outside of my household, Stop visiting friends and family who are older, immune-compromised, or otherwise at greater risk from coronavirus, Wear a mask when I go out in public, Stop attending religious services in person , and Stay inside my home except for absolute emergencies. These were measured on a five-point scale from “Extremely willing” to “Not willing at all.”
•	Approval of Democrats and Republicans actions’: We asked respondents to rate the job done by six different political actors: Donald Trump, Your state elected officials, “Democrats in Congress,” “Republicans in Congress,” “The Democratic Party in general,” and “The Republican Party in general.” These questions used a six-point scale from “Perfect Job” to “Terrible Job.”
•	Beliefs about pandemic effects: We asked participants how many Americans they expected would die from coronavirus during the next year, when they expected a vaccine for coronavirus to become available, and when they expected life to return to normal in the U.S.

Additionally, three batteries measured concepts where we expected all respondents, regardless of partisan identification, to move in the same direction. 
•	Trust in future government actions: We asked participants how much they trusted four actors to, going forward, do the right thing when it comes to the coronavirus pandemic: “The federal government,” “The state government where you live,” “The local government where you live,” and “Health officials.” These used a five-point scale from “Trust a great deal,” to “Don’t trust at all.”
•	Cynicism about government action: We asked two items using a seven-point agree disagree format: “In response to the coronavirus outbreak, politicians are pursuing their own personal interests instead of the public good,” and “Elected officials are doing their best to protect everyone from the coronavirus outbreak.” The second was reverse-coded.
•	Interest in consuming pandemic news: Finally, we asked two items measuring interest in consuming pandemic-related news: “In the future, how interested are you following news about the coronavirus outbreak?,” and “How important do you think it is for you to stay informed about the coronavirus outbreak?” These used a five-point scale from “Extremely interested/important” to “Not at all interested/important.”

For each set of dependent variables we will create an index of all items used to measure that variable. If the reliability of the resulting scale is below .7, we will drop items from the index until the reliability is above .7, dropping the items that detract most from scale reliability first. We will then analyze the dropped items individually, or as a second index if, for some index created from the dropped items, scale reliability is above .7. For approval of actors’ actions we will create separate indices for Republicans and Democratic elites (ignoring the state officials questions).

For the first five sets of dependent variables we measure the heterogeneous treatment effects among Democrats and Republicans of the partisan conflict and partisan game frame conditions as compared to the non-partisan condition. We define Democrats as all respondents who identify as Democrats plus all independents who lean towards the democrats; we define Republicans similarly. This will be our primary analysis, though we may run auxiliary analyses breaking down results by partisan strength. We analyze the treatment-by-covariate interaction by regressing the outcome on treatment status, partisanship, and treatment status interacted with partisanship. For the final three set of dependent variables we measure the mean difference between partisan conflict and partisan game frame conditions as compared to the non-partisan condition. We generate p-values and confidence intervals using randomization inference, implemented using the ri package for R, version 0.9.

q19.value: We will use two-tailed tests with alpha = .1.

q21.value: We will use pairwise deletion for missing responses.

q23.value:
Prims, J.P.Y., and Matt Motyl. 2018. A Tool for Detecting Low Quality Data in Internet Research. SICLab. R. https://github.com/SICLab/detecting-bots (April 2, 2019).

Kennedy, Ryan et al. 2019. The Shape of and Solutions to the MTurk Quality Crisis. Rochester, NY: Social Science Research Network. SSRN Scholarly Paper. https://papers.ssrn.com/abstract=3272468.

registration_responses.q2:
H1: Compared to the non-partisan frame condition, the partisan conflict frame will increase concern about coronavirus, support for mitigation strategies, willingness to engage in personal health behaviors; will decrease approval of actors’ actions; and will worsen beliefs about the pandemic’s effects more among Democrats than among Republicans.

H2: Compared to the non-partisan frame condition, the partisan game frame will increase concern about coronavirus, support for mitigation strategies, willingness to engage in personal health behaviors; will decrease approval of actors’ actions; and will worsen beliefs about the pandemic’s effects more among Democrats than among Republicans.

H3: Compared to the partisan conflict frame condition, the partisan game frame will increase concern about coronavirus, support for mitigation strategies, willingness to engage in personal health behaviors; will decrease approval of actors’ actions; and will worsen beliefs about the pandemic’s effects more among Democrats than among Republicans.

H4: Compared to the non-partisan frame condition, the partisan conflict frame condition will decrease trust, increase cynicism, and increase interest in consuming pandemic news.

H5: Compared to the non-partisan frame condition, the partisan game frame condition will decrease trust, increase cynicism, and increase interest in consuming pandemic news.

H6: Compared to the partisan conflict frame condition, the partisan game frame condition will decrease trust, increase cynicism, and increase interest in consuming pandemic news.

H7a: Compared to the non-partisan frame condition, the partisan game frame condition will increase affective polarization among Republicans.

H7b: Compared to the non-partisan frame condition, the partisan game frame condition will increase affective polarization among Democrats.

q4: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

Prims, J.P.Y., and Matt Motyl. 2018. A Tool for Detecting Low Quality Data in Internet Research. SICLab. R. https://github.com/SICLab/detecting-bots (April 2, 2019).

Kennedy, Ryan et al. 2019. The Shape of and Solutions to the MTurk Quality Crisis. Rochester, NY: Social Science Research Network. SSRN Scholarly Paper. https://papers.ssrn.com/abstract=3272468.
registration_responses.q6.question:
We employ a three-condition experiment to evaluate the effect of conflict and game-framing on attitudes and beliefs about the COVID-19 pandemic. In each condition participants read three news stories about the pandemic that were framed in non-partisan, partisan conflict, or partisan game frames. There were two partisan game-frame conditions; in one, Democrats were portrayed as winning in two of the three stories, in the other Republicans were portrayed as winning in two of the three stories. After reading these stories, participants answered several batteries of questions measuring concern about the pandemic, support for mitigation strategies, approval of various actors’ responses to the pandemic, personal health behaviors adopted in response to the pandemic, beliefs about the effects of the pandemic, trust in political actors to manage the pandemic going forward, cynicism about the government response, and interest in consuming news about the pandemic.

All participants first read a short article describing a brief timeline of COVID-19 related events going back to the first detection of the disease in Wuhan, China. This article was intended to set common expectations about the purpose of the experiment; further, time spent on this article served as a pre-treatment attention check, since all participants read the same article. After this article, participants read three articles about different aspects of the COVID-19 pandemic. One article was about Senate negotiations over the two trillion dollar “phase three” stimulus bill signed into law on March 27th, one about the lack of testing available in parts of the United States, and one about…? All articles were based on actual articles in the New York Times or Washington Post and were shortened considerably to 250-300 words. In the non-partisan condition, the headline and text of these articles were adapted to emphasis the substantive impact of the legislation and to remove direct references to partisanship or partisan conflict. In the partisan conflict condition the headlines and text were altered to emphasize partisan disagreement and fighting over the issue. In the game frame condition the headlines and text were adapted to advance a claim that one party was “winning” and another “losing” because of the issue; one article portrayed the Democrats as winning, one the Republicans, and one that both sides claimed victory. Full treatment text is as an attachment.

(2019) to remove likely bots and non-US respondents using VPS services. We will also remove subjects who spend less than eight seconds on the first, common article.

attributes.title: Are pain information published on social media in accordance with the recommended? A Cross-Sectional Study.
attributes.description: A cross-sectional study of the most accessed YouTube videos on pain treatment will be conducted.

q1.value: Juliana Pereira Silva, Luana Aparecida Soares, Vinicius Cunha Oliveira

q2.value: The videos on pain management available on social media, mainly on You Tube, do not comply with the guidelines for clinical recommendations.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A cross-sectional study of the most accessed YouTube videos (http://www.youtube.com) on pain treatment will be carried out. The first two hundred videos with free access from the YouTube site will be considered, admitting that users are rarely used to going beyond the first results of any search, being the most watched videos.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
A cross-sectional study of the most accessed YouTube videos (http://www.youtube.com) on pain treatment will be carried out. The first two hundred videos with free access from the YouTube site will be considered, admitting that users are rarely used to going beyond the first results of any search, being the most watched videos.
All the videos recorded in Brazilian Portuguese and English available with free access on the referred website will be defined as inclusion criteria for the study using the following terms in the search bar: “Pain treatment” and “Pain Treatment”.
Exclusion criteria will include: a) videos that are not related to musculoskeletal pain; b) duplicated videos, partially or totally, will be considered the one with the highest number of views; c) videos that are not recorded in Portuguese or English.

q11.value: Will be considered the first two hundred videos with free access from the YouTube website.

q12.value: The first two hundred videos with free access from the YouTube site will be considered, admitting that users are rarely used to going beyond the first results of any search, being the most watched videos.

question.value:
number of views; number of likes; number of dislikes; and number of comments. The possible explanatory factors investigated will be: date of publication; language; duration; video source; domain area; intention of the videos; video category; financing; number of items in accordance with the recommendations of the MSK pain management guideline and intention of comments. 
Then, the videos will be classified according to their content, in: Not useful (0), Not very useful (1-3), Moderately useful (4-7) and Very useful (8-11), in order to check if the video can be used as a complementary tool for pain education.

The analysis  exploratory analysis will be performed through descriptive and inferential statistics. Then, the analysis of multiple variables will be performed through logistic regression to investigate the factors associated with the popularity of the videos. Possible associations will be analyzed using the simple Odds Ratio (OR) and adjusted with their respective 95% confidence intervals (p <0.05).

q22.value: The analysis  exploratory analysis will be performed through descriptive and inferential statistics.

attributes.title: Manipulation von IAT-Effekten durch evaluatives Lernen - Eine Überprüfung mit dem ReAL Modell
attributes.description: Former studies showed that implicit attitudes/IAT-effects can not just be manipulated by experience based learning procedures (e.g. evaluative conditioning) but also by presentation of verbal evaluative statements. Though this can hardly be explained by dual-process theories of evaluative processes, which form the basis of the IAT, these results can raise the question, which processes underlie the IAT and its effects. One can assume that in addition to implicit attitudes there are further processes that can effect subject's behavior in the IAT-procedure. Replicating the effects of repeated evaluative pairings (evaluative conditioning) and evaluative statements on IAT by using the ReAL-Model of the IAT, could promote a better understanding of the particular processes that are effected by these manipulations. The ReAL-Model can discriminate between 4 processes which drive behavior that leads to an IAT-Effect: the Recoding of the task in the compatible block of the IAT, the associations between target and attribute, and the Label-based identification of the correct response. There is the hypothesis, that the two types of manipulation have a differential effect on those processes.

q1.value: Manipulation von IAT-Effekten durch evaluatives Lernen - Eine Überprüfung mit dem ReAL Modell

q3.value:
Former studies showed that implicit attitudes/IAT-effects can not just be manipulated by experience based learning procedures (e.g. evaluative conditioning) but also by presentation of verbal evaluative statements. Though this can hardly be explained by dual-process theories of evaluative processes, which form the basis of the IAT, these results can raise the question, which processes underlie the IAT and its effects. One can assume that in addition to implicit attitudes there are further processes that can effect subject's behavior in the IAT-procedure. Replicating the effects of repeated evaluative pairings (evaluative conditioning) and evaluative statements on IAT by using the ReAL-Model of the IAT, could promote a better understanding of the particular processes that are effected by these manipulations. The ReAL-Model can discriminate between 4 processes which drive behavior that leads to an IAT-Effect: the Recoding of the task in the compatible block of the IAT, the associations between target and attribute, and the Label-based identification of the correct response. There is the hypothesis, that the two types of manipulation have a differential effect on those processes.
In this study, we will manipulate participants attitudes towards squares and rectangles either with repeated evaluative pairings (REP) or with evaluative statements (ES) and measure the changes in implicit attitudes by using the ReAL-IAT.

q4.value:
The average Association-parameter of the REP-Manipulation group will significantly differ from the one in the control-group according to the direction of manipulation.
The average Association-parameter in the ES-Group will not significantly differ from the one in the control-group.

The average Recoding-parameter of the REP-Manipulation group will not significantly differ from the one in the control group.
The average Recoding-parameter of the ES-Manipulation group will be significantly higher than the one in the REP-manipulation and control group.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Between subject design with 3 factors: 
1. group: control group, REP, ES (3 levels)
2. direction of manipulation: squares positive, rectangles positive (2 levels)
3. Blockorder in the ReAL-IAT: compatible first, incompatible first (2 levels)

Those factors lead to 10 combinations: 2 for control group, 4 for REP and 4 for ES.

q9.value:
Balanced randomization: Participants will select themselves into conditions with fixed amount of participants without knowing the differences between the conditions.
The fixed amounts lead to an equal number of participants in Control group (32) , REP-group (32) and ES-group (32).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants mainly will be students of psychology recruited through a mailing-list of the institute of psychology of the FSU Jena. Participants will be rewarded with test-subject hours.

q13.value: We will collect data of 96 subjects. As described at randomization there will be 32 participants in each condition (control, REP, ES).

q14.value: We chose sample size of 96 because of reasons of research-economics and practicability/realizability in context of a bachelor thesis.

question.value:
We will manipulate the type of manipulation/learning-procedure. The three Levels of treatment are control group (no manipulation), REP-group (manipulation by repeated evaluative pairings), ES-group (manipulation by evaluative statements).
We will balance for direction of manipulation and IAT-blockorder.
The main outcome variables will be the parameters of the ReAL-Model, in particular the Association-parameters and the Recoding-parameters of the 3 groups.

To test differences of ReAL-parameters between groups we will conduct a series of planed contrasts. We will subtract the distribution for each parameter in one group from the distribution of this parameter in another group. This enables us to test the significance of differences between groups by estimating the expectation of the resulting distribution and its 95%-CI. We will conduct the following contrasts for the Association Parameters and the Recoding-Parameter.

1. REP-group vs. control-group
2. ES-group vs. control-group
3. REP-group vs. ES-group

If however this analysis method does not work in the intended way, we will use t-Tests and ANOVAs to test significance of average-parameter differences between groups.

q21.value: We will use the criteria of expectation and its 95%-confidence interval of the difference distribution for determining if the parameters differ significantly between groups. If the 95%-confidence interval does not contain zero, we will determine, that the concerned parameter differs significantly between the groups.

q22.value: We want to exclude participants that click through the experiment randomly and do not stick to the task. We will do this by the following criteria: participants with reaction times less than 200ms in 30% of all trials or with an error rate larger than 40% will be excluded from the data analysis.

registration_responses.q1: Manipulation von IAT-Effekten durch evaluatives Lernen - Eine Überprüfung mit dem ReAL Modell
registration_responses.q3:
Former studies showed that implicit attitudes/IAT-effects can not just be manipulated by experience based learning procedures (e.g. evaluative conditioning) but also by presentation of verbal evaluative statements. Though this can hardly be explained by dual-process theories of evaluative processes, which form the basis of the IAT, these results can raise the question, which processes underlie the IAT and its effects. One can assume that in addition to implicit attitudes there are further processes that can effect subject's behavior in the IAT-procedure. Replicating the effects of repeated evaluative pairings (evaluative conditioning) and evaluative statements on IAT by using the ReAL-Model of the IAT, could promote a better understanding of the particular processes that are effected by these manipulations. The ReAL-Model can discriminate between 4 processes which drive behavior that leads to an IAT-Effect: the Recoding of the task in the compatible block of the IAT, the associations between target and attribute, and the Label-based identification of the correct response. There is the hypothesis, that the two types of manipulation have a differential effect on those processes.
In this study, we will manipulate participants attitudes towards squares and rectangles either with repeated evaluative pairings (REP) or with evaluative statements (ES) and measure the changes in implicit attitudes by using the ReAL-IAT.

The average Association-parameter in the ES-Group will not significantly differ from the one in the control-group.

The average Recoding-parameter of the REP-Manipulation group will not significantly differ from the one in the control group.
The average Recoding-parameter of the ES-Manipulation group will be significantly higher than the one in the REP-manipulation and control group.

registration_responses.q8.question:
Between subject design with 3 factors: 
1. group: control group, REP, ES (3 levels)
2. direction of manipulation: squares positive, rectangles positive (2 levels)
3. Blockorder in the ReAL-IAT: compatible first, incompatible first (2 levels)

Those factors lead to 10 combinations: 2 for control group, 4 for REP and 4 for ES.
registration_responses.q12.question: Participants mainly will be students of psychology recruited through a mailing-list of the institute of psychology of the FSU Jena. Participants will be rewarded with test-subject hours.
registration_responses.q16.question:
We will manipulate the type of manipulation/learning-procedure. The three Levels of treatment are control group (no manipulation), REP-group (manipulation by repeated evaluative pairings), ES-group (manipulation by evaluative statements).
We will balance for direction of manipulation and IAT-blockorder.
registration_responses.q17.question: The main outcome variables will be the parameters of the ReAL-Model, in particular the Association-parameters and the Recoding-parameters of the 3 groups.
registration_responses.q19.question:
To test differences of ReAL-parameters between groups we will conduct a series of planed contrasts. We will subtract the distribution for each parameter in one group from the distribution of this parameter in another group. This enables us to test the significance of differences between groups by estimating the expectation of the resulting distribution and its 95%-CI. We will conduct the following contrasts for the Association Parameters and the Recoding-Parameter.

1. REP-group vs. control-group
2. ES-group vs. control-group
3. REP-group vs. ES-group

If however this analysis method does not work in the intended way, we will use t-Tests and ANOVAs to test significance of average-parameter differences between groups.

attributes.title: VNH
attributes.description: This is a pre-registration ahead of data collection for the "Varying the Number of Hypotheses" study (abbreviation: VNH).

summary.value: This is our pre-analysis plan in the document "200411 VNH pre-analysis plan.docx"

registration_responses.summary: This is our pre-analysis plan in the document "200411 VNH pre-analysis plan.docx"

attributes.title: Personality Change and Sustainability Attitudes and Behaviors in NZAVS
attributes.description: The goal of this study is to examine longitudinal association of personality trait change and sustainability attitudes and behaviors.

summary.value:
Previous research has documented cross-sectional correlations between personality traits, such as neuroticism (N), extraversion (E), Openness (O), agreeableness (A), conscientiousness (C), and Honesty (H), and sustainability attitudes and behaviors (SABs; Brick & Lewis, 2016; Hirsh, 2010; Lee et al., 2015; Markowitz et al., 2012; Milfont & Sibley, 2012; Milfont et al., 2015). The goals of this study are to a) replicate and extend these associations across eight distinct SABs and b) examine whether changes in these personality traits are related to changes in SABs across 10 yearly waves of data. To do this, we will use the New Zealand Attitudes and Values Survey (NZAVS), a representative sample of 47,951 participants from New Zealand assessed yearly for 10 years. 

A specific hypotheses and research plan is attached to this preregistration.

registration_responses.summary:
Previous research has documented cross-sectional correlations between personality traits, such as neuroticism (N), extraversion (E), Openness (O), agreeableness (A), conscientiousness (C), and Honesty (H), and sustainability attitudes and behaviors (SABs; Brick & Lewis, 2016; Hirsh, 2010; Lee et al., 2015; Markowitz et al., 2012; Milfont & Sibley, 2012; Milfont et al., 2015). The goals of this study are to a) replicate and extend these associations across eight distinct SABs and b) examine whether changes in these personality traits are related to changes in SABs across 10 yearly waves of data. To do this, we will use the New Zealand Attitudes and Values Survey (NZAVS), a representative sample of 47,951 participants from New Zealand assessed yearly for 10 years. 

A specific hypotheses and research plan is attached to this preregistration.
